history.content:
You can take Stat 135 or Stat 151A.

182 is very helpful for ML.

If you have taken 186, then 194 is not that useful (I am taking 186 right now and instructor Prof. Parameswaran replied in 186 piazza).

Here is the reply: 

Thanks for your interest! We're still in the very early stages of figuring out what might be in this class, but here is a brief description: https://tiny.cc/data-engg-info

At the highest level, the goal of the class is to act as a systems complement to algorithmic data 100, and to act as a user-facing/data sci-lifecycle complement to more database internals-y cs186. So there will definitely be some overlap with cs186, but the exact extent of overlap is not clear. 

Edit: I spoke to Joe this AM, and our current take is that we are discouraging students who have taken cs186 from taking data engineering.  In the future, there may be less overlap between the two classes, so a typical sequencing might be to take data engineering and then cs186.  But for now, this will allow us to factor out whatever we think is most important for the data engineering class without worrying about the overlap.

children.subject: I think 151A is more useful, and it is much easier.

Thank you! That's good to know about the Data Engineering course since I already took CS 186. I've also taken STAT 135, but have also heard that STAT 150 could be useful for data science related careers. Do you think 150 or 151A would be more useful?

history.content:
I am a senior in EECS who will be graduating next semester, so looking for suggestions 

of great must-take classes! I'm very interested in data science, so some of my favorite upper div classes so far have been DS 100, PROB 140, and DS 102 (currently taking). I also really do enjoy probability/stats, so I'm currently taking STAT 153 which I find really interesting. 

I am currently considering taking CS 182 (have taken 188/189 already) and/or CS 194 (Data Engineering) next semester. Does anyone have any insights into what these classes are like, or if there any other stat classes that would be particularly useful for someone interested in data science/analytics?
history.subject: Looking for great cs or stat classes to take in last semester!
